—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to speak on the Corporations Law Amendment (Employee Entitlements) Bill 2000. It is very good to win a point in this game. I am very pleased that sensible heads prevailed and that we can debate this bill.

speech.para: As I said, since the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, got into bed with Patrick Stevedores and taught them how to rip-off working people, a lot of other corporates have learnt the tricks. We have gone down that road, with the Oakdales, the Merrywoods, the Cobar miners, the Braybrook workers and also National Textiles. This bill does not give enough protection to working people, and it will certainly take much more than this bill to have something in the statutes that will give protection to working people.

This bill introduces a new offence to penalise persons who deliberately enter into agreements or transactions for the purpose of avoiding payments of employee entitlements. But it is always very difficult to prove in those sorts of situations that somebody has deliberately gone into something to avoid payment. The bill deems that a company incurs debt for the purpose of insolvent trading provisions when it enters into an uncommercial transaction, thereby extending the current duty on directors not to engage in insolvent trading. It also states that the bill, when passed, will operate from the assent of the Governor-General; therefore, the directors of National Textiles, of course, and other companies that have recently become insolvent will not be subject to the new offence provisions of this bill. It is very convenient for the many who have already gone that way but have managed to use the government to absolve them of their responsibilities. While looking like it has something solid on paper, I am concerned that the bill will do little to act as a serious deterrent to stop directors from failing to provide for employee entitlements.

There are serious defects in this bill. The first deficiency can be found in the detailing of the new offence. This will assist only where it can be shown that a director had intended preventing recovery of the entitlements of employees or significantly reducing their entitlements that could be recovered. I believe it would be almost impossible to find evidence that someone had deliberately prevented or reduced the recovery of entitlements. It is a very subjective way of dealing with the problem. There are no means by which anyone really can test that. Secondly, there is no retrospectivity to the legislation, so those people who have already been hit before this legislation becomes law will miss out. There are a number of workers in Tasmania who were hoping to get some assistance to make claims for their own wages and other entitlements under some sort of protection from this bill. Many have worked for many years for one company in particular that I know of.

The second part of the bill deals with orders of the court. I started off by saying that, since Mr Reith got into bed with Patrick Stevedores and they then had a company that did not have any money in the bank, the rest of corporate Australia, the ones that have got a little bit, have learned how to manipulate the system and are now closing up shop and taking the workers' entitlements with them. The government, running scared, has brought this bill into the parliament, but it is not going to solve the problem. It is not going to look after workers' entitlements and it will fail to do that. It is a very mean bill. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a pity that the calling of quorums forced the government to truncate debate on this important bill, the Corporations Law Amendment (Employee Entitlements) Bill 2000. It is really bloody-mindedness on both sides that brings no credit to this place when there are members who want to contribute to the debate on this crucial piece of legislation that has been occupying the minds not only of people in this parliament but indeed of every worker in the rapidly casualising workplace out there who are insecure about not only their day-to-day job prospects but whether their entitlements might be there at the end of it all.

speech.para: I support the passage of this bill, not because I think it will solve the problem of ensuring that employees get their legal entitlements when their employers go belly up but because it is a small step in the right direction towards protecting those entitlements. I should say at the outset that the Labor Party should hang its head in shame for its failure to deal with this issue while in government. It is not as though businesses started going belly up in 1996. In 1999 over 7,000 companies became insolvent, owing employees between $140 million and $181 million, depending on which estimate you rely on. But I daresay that in many of the years of Labor's 13-year term, especially during the recession, that figure rose quite rapidly.

The bill really only does two things: it prohibits an employer from entering into an arrangement with an intention to prevent the recovery of entitlements of employees of a company, or significantly reduce the amount of the entitlements of employees of a company that can be recovered; and it adds an extra duty to company directors so that they become personally liable for corporate debts arising from entering into uncommercial contracts when insolvent. There is a whole lot I was going to say on this, and I do not want to prolong the debate unnecessarily, but it strikes me, as it does many people out there, that the key to achieving any sort of fairness in this whole area is to make directors far more accountable for the situations that arise when a company does go belly up. I know we have been talking about all sorts of highly publicised cases. I notice that the minister's discussion paper examines the schemes in the United Kingdom, Belgium, Brazil, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Greece, Ireland—it sounds like the Treasurer's GST list—Italy, Japan, Mexico, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden and the United States, but not Botswana. These countries deal with the issue of employees' entitlements on insolvency through a range of measures, ranging from enhanced priority to compulsory insurance. I note that for some reason the discussion paper declined to include Canada among the cases studied. I would ask the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who is at the table, to explain why that happened. It may just be a coincidence but, unlike those other countries, Canada has legislation which imposes personal liability on directors for non-payment of workers' entitlements. In Canada at the federal level, directors are liable for up to six months wages.

We have seen the national headlines that covered issues like the Cobar, Woodlawn and Oakdale mines, National Textiles and Braybrook Manufacturing, but what about those thousands of smaller company crashes we never hear about? How about the story I heard the other day of Lithgow Motors, which went belly up in 1991, its 10 employees receiving no payout at all? The employees made claims for outstanding wages but found that they were fifth on the list for any sort of payment. They were advised by lawyers that, even though certain debts of the business were recovered for GIO, there were no dividends payable to unsecured creditors such as the employees. Nor were their solicitors able to obtain a copy of the account of the receiver. A year later the solicitors informed employees that, because there were no reporting requirements for a mortgagee in possession, it was not possible to obtain these amounts. Ten employees of this small company received no payment at all for wages due, holiday pay and other entitlements. The employee who spoke to me believes that the assets of the company were hidden and feels this is confirmed by the former owner suffering no apparent hiccup in his lifestyle, right down to the continued business ventures and luxury car he operates to this day. I see nothing in this bill that will enable the former employees of the defunct Lithgow Motors to recover their entitlements.

This bill and the safety net proposals to follow are inadequate responses to a problem that is exacerbated by the already insecure climate of today's workplace—a workplace where a worker is more often regarded as a unit of cost rather than a valued and valuable contributor to the performance of the company, its shareholders and of course those well paid executives and directors whose bloated salaries depend on the output of the work force they are so ready to swindle.

talk.start.para: —I too would have liked to have spoken at greater length on this issue. The whole issue of employee entitlements is something that is very dear to the hearts of people on this side of the House. This bill, the Corporations Law Amendment (Employee Entitlements) Bill 2000, seeks to penalise directors who trade when the company is insolvent, who make incorrect managerial decisions relating to the directorship of their companies which then lead them to not being able to pay their workers' entitlements.

speech.para: This is not enough. It does not make the directors personally liable for the loss of their employees' entitlements. It does not make them forgo their millions of dollars, as the member for Calare just alluded to, to pay out their workers' entitlements when decisions that they have made have affected the insolvency of their company. The member for Calare mentioned a couple of smaller companies. He also referred to the very public companies going belly up, with the loss of employee entitlements, which have happened over the past few years. I would like to refer to those examples. They really tell the story of this government.

The member for Lyons mentioned the fact that Minister Reith jumped into bed with Patrick Stevedores and taught the corporate world how to rearrange their corporate assets to allow for the attack on workers in their workplace. Last year, the copper mine at Cobar became insolvent—the first major one in my first term in this parliament—and the workers were left facing non-receipt of their correct entitlements. It was the strength and solidarity of the CFMEU which compelled the government to force the Australian Securities and Investment Commission to force the parent company, Ashanti, to come up with the dollars to pay their workers' entitlements. We had Sizzler restaurants going belly up all over the country. Because they were a fairly non-unionised work force, because they were young, casual workers and because their workplaces were fragmented, they did not have that kind of support behind them to be able to force the government to make some kind of decision and those workers—mainly young kids—walked away without any entitlements being paid.

In the case of the Oakdale workers, once again they were supported and, in solidarity with their union, the CFMEU, they forced the government to pass some legislation, not for the government to bail out the company but to allow these workers to access their own money, to pay out their entitlements, even though they were all left without a job and their communities were suffering.

Then we had the Braybrook Manufacturing workers, a bunch of women, mainly from non-English-speaking backgrounds in Victoria. Their company went belly up, I think, on 6 September. However, on 31 August last year the minister announced that he would put in place legislation to protect workers' entitlements. When he made that announcement, he could have said that that legislation would come into force from 31 August. If he had said that, then the Braybrook Manufacturing workers would have had some of their entitlements protected. But the minister did not do that; he put it in place from 1 January this year.

Then we had the workers at National Textiles. Once again, it was a strongly unionised, organised workplace. The company went belly up and the workers were left without their entitlements. They formed the picket line up at Rutherford and it was only because the Prime Minister's brother was a director of National Textiles that the government put its hand into taxpayers' money and came up with the protection so that those workers could receive their entitlements. The examples go on and on. Linda workers down in Victoria face the same situation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In July 1999, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation indicated that he was intending to `move quickly' in relation to the matter which is presently before the House. From July to March might be quick in the minister's view, but given the urgency of the need for some action and given the very high profile corporate collapses that other speakers have referred to, it is really not adequate in terms of promptness in bringing matters before the House. The Corporations Law Amendment (Employee Entitlements) Bill 2000 is quite disappointing in a number of respects. It really shows that the government has not considered a number of quite important issues which ought to have been considered in the context of Corporations Law reform. For example, the legislation does not address the misuse of employee entitlements prior to insolvency and it does not propose a means by which employees, who become aware that proper provisioning is not being made for their entitlements or that their superannuation contributions are not being made, can commence preventive action.

speech.para: The government ought to have considered amending the Corporations Law to enable an application to be made to court for a related corporation to pay the debts of an insolvent corporation along the lines foreshadowed by the member for Brisbane in the Employment Security Bill which he introduced some time ago. The government should have considered, but obviously has not, amending the Corporations Law to remove barriers which employees currently face in bringing actions against directors under the insolvent trading provisions. There was a range of impediments—cost and complexity—but there is not time to develop them in this very limited debate. The public policy would certainly have benefited from some indication in this debate of the government's contemplation of initiatives in that respect. Obviously, the government has not considered making directors personally liable where they have not made proper provision, whether by way of a trust, insurance or some other means, for employees' entitlements.

The bill is a pretty basic set of proposals which just do not go far enough. The government has introduced a new part 5.8A to the Corporations Law with the stated intention of protecting a company's employees from agreements entered into with the intention of defeating recovery of entitle-ments. The central provision here is intent. The burden of proving subjectively that a person intended to avoid recovery of employee entitlements may mean that successful actions for compensation will be extremely rare.

An objective rather than a subjective test applies and is sufficient if the company incurs a debt while insolvent or becomes insolvent as a result of incurring a debt and there are reasonable grounds for suspecting it may or may not have become insolvent. No explanation is offered by the government in this debate as to why they are imposing a more onerous evidentiary burden in the sorts of cases that are being dealt with here than the objective test that they apply to other areas.

Other jurisdictions impose liability on directors for non-payment without requiring proof of intent—the subjective test. For example, the Queensland Industrial Relations Act provides that directors may be liable for a failure to pay an employee's wages or a failure to contribute to occupational superannuation. Canada, I understand, has comparable legislation to that in Queensland.

In addition, where a company enters into a deed of arrangement, there will be no scope for either the liquidator or employees to bring an action to recover compensation for a breach. Of course, a criminal prosecution can be brought by ASIC. However, we are seeing many press reports presently about ASIC's limited resources in relation to its capacity to deal with those sorts of areas of its responsibility. The bill does not alter the current priority arrangements on the list of creditors that are provided to employees. Even such well-known `left-wing' organisations as the Australian Institute of Company Directors have recently indicated that accrued benefits should have priority over other creditors. So it is not a particularly radical proposal, given that particular source. The legislation is inadequate in other respects as well. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to effectively summarise the amendments in the Corporations Law Amendment (Employee Entitlements) Bill 2000. Unfortunately, we have had a truncated debate. The opposition chose to make the House almost unworkable this afternoon, and we have had to bring on this debate and move it on.

speech.para: I would like to address specific issues raised particularly by members of the opposition about the provisions of the bill. The bill of itself is not designed to be a general safety net to ensure that all entitlements are paid. As the opposition has acknowledged, companies often fail through no fault of the directors. The government is taking other steps to provide a general safety net for all employees, and it is looking carefully at the insurance system to address these situations. The member for Wills raised the idea of ranking employee entitlements ahead of a floating charge. I am advised that is already the law and has been for a number of years.

The bill is designed to address deliberate avoidance. Where deliberate avoidance is shown, there are means to secure a compensation not just from directors or from other companies in a group but from any person who is party to unacceptable transactions and arrangements. I think this addresses the issue raised by the member for Calare, who I note is not around to hear the end of the debate. It is therefore more widely and better targeted than those proposals put forward by the opposition to address this issue. Those proposals focused not on the objectionable conduct but on the more uncertain test of whether or not a company is part of a corporate group. The member for Wills also said that the bill does not provide for compensation for employees and that it just introduces an offence. That is not true. There are provisions for compensation actions in the bill itself. To facilitate actions during a liquidation by employees, they specifically provide that actions can be brought to the civil standard of proof, whether or not an offence is proven.

Furthermore, in the existing Corporations Law, there are various avenues to obtain compensation where provisions are breached, including the new provision, and ASIC can take action under them. The member for Wills also claimed that the amendment to section 588G to expand insolvent trading would not work if no debt was incurred. It is precisely that issue that the bill addresses. It effectively deems an uncommercial transaction to be a debt for that purpose. Accordingly, if uncommercial transactions are entered into whilst the company is technically insolvent, as has been the case for a considerable period of time, the directors will be civilly and personally liable. All the compensatory remedies available for insolvent trading will continue to apply to the broadened notion of insolvent trading under the bill.

It was finally suggested that we should not have an intent element in the offence provision so that it would be easier to prove a breach. The problem with that approach is that nearly all transactions involving the outlay of company funds can potentially impact on creditors, including employees. A prohibition against entering into any transaction arrangement that potentially affected employee entitlements is therefore unworkable. You would effectively be banning trading altogether, which would, of course, be a ludicrous outcome. It only makes sense to have such a blanket prohibition when the company is insolvent, and we already have an insolvent trading duty, which is strengthened under this bill. The new offence in the bill applies at all times, regardless of whether a company is insolvent or not.

Finally, the Ministerial Council for Corporations, which I chair, carried forward the first two of the three proposals in July last year, which were addressed. That was when I put out the release. In relation to the third proposal, Minco was of the view that we should deal with all the issues at one time rather than have separate legislation. This legislation requires the approval and support of and consultation with all states and territories. Given that scenario, it is important that we address all the issues at one time so as not to create any uncertainty. I therefore commend the bill to the House.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Hockey)—by leave—read a third time.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise tonight to speak about the gravely important issue of child abuse in this country. In doing so, I wish to propose that a purple ribbon day be designated for the last sitting day of this session of parliament, in late June. Purple signifies compassion, and I am indebted to Jan Watson at Wyong, who has been very active over the last few years in seeking, in her area and beyond, to raise community awareness of the problem of child abuse.

speech.para: The purple ribbon project began in Australia on the Gold Coast in 1994 and was taken up by the Central Coast in 1997. Wyong Shire Council adopted the project, declaring that July would be recognised as purple ribbon month on an annual basis. The intention of the project is to establish nationally the month of July as purple ribbon month. Each year during July, people will be asked to wear a small purple ribbon as a silent protest against the extent of child abuse in the community. Of course, Mr Speaker, I would like to see the purpose of it also being to raise awareness of this problem in our community. As I have indicated, the colour purple was chosen as it is a spiritual colour signifying compassion.

Mr Speaker, you would be aware that I have written to you on this matter. I fully understand the response that I will be getting, because we have discussed it over the phone with your staff, that there may be difficulties in terms of the precedent setting of, in some completely formal way, establishing a purple ribbon day leading into purple ribbon month. But you have indicated that there is nothing to stop members of parliament from wearing purple ribbons. Can I suggest that, on a voluntary basis, members of both sides of the House on that particular day may like to take the opportunity of the adjournment debate, which is taking up no extra time of the parliament, to talk about the problem of child abuse in this country, because it is vitally important that we do so.

I would like to draw the attention of this House and, through it, the Australian people to the magnitude of the problem of child abuse in Australia. According to figures released by the Abused Child Trust, 70 per cent of prisoners were abused as children; 43 per cent of psychiatric patients have been victims of abuse; and, each year, 50,000 Australian children are abused. These are truly terrifying statistics because these children do not get the protection that they deserve. In my own state of Queensland, in the latest year for which statistics are available, 1997-98, it appears that there were 5,362 victims of child abuse. I will just break those down: 28 homicide and related offences, 2,844 acts intended to cause injury, 2,321 cases of sexual assault and related offences, and 169 cases of neglect of a person under care.
Sadly, this is a very topical issue. On the front page of the Daily Telegraph today is the headline `Lost lives: 70 children who died despite warnings they were in danger'. The article says:

quote.para: Seventy at-risk children have died in NSW during the past three years despite being known to the Department of Community Services, a new report has revealed.

speech.para: On this revelation, it says:

quote.para: NSW Children's Commissioner Gillian Calvert said DOCS and the community at large must be `more vigilant' in recognising children at risk and reporting their parents.

speech.para: Community services minister Mrs Lo Po said that `authorities had been forced to accept the word of parents who had made hollow promises to give up their destructive habits'. She further said:

quote.para: I have had a gutful—and I think the community has as well—of watching parents who are unfit to be parents ...' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is not the time for questions and answers to the Speaker, but I should indicate that the member for Rankin has very fairly portrayed both the support and the reservations of my office.

subdebateinfo.title: Gilmore Electorate: Visit by Prime Minister and Cabinet

talk.start.para: —When I first suggested that we ask the Prime Minister to come to my electorate of Gilmore, the question most asked of me was, `Why?' followed by, `I bet he doesn't want to come.' Regardless, we pushed on. After many months of waiting the call came: Prime Minister John Howard and his cabinet were coming to town. The logistics of such an event are just enormous, and I am so glad that Carol, Ruth and their teams were there to guide us. We had been lucky enough to have the Prime Minister visit on his own before and we thought we knew all about security measures. But, no, we did not know at all. To me it is a reflection of shame that the state police, the Federal Police and the other security people have to go to the lengths that they do. I have always tended to think that such measures are only necessary in other countries.

speech.para: However, the good thing was that most of the preparations were in place before people realised what was about to happen. For this I have to thank Shoalhaven City Council; the Mayor, Greg Watson, and his council; and especially the staff for their assistance in what was for them, I am sure, a day of total frustration. All were excellent and remained friendly, helpful and flexible in their approach at all times. I thank our police force for their unobtrusiveness on the day and for making sure all was kept low key to avoid any antagonism. The councillors had to agree to move their regular meeting to another week so that we could have the council chamber for the cabinet meeting. This they did without question. Marie from the mayor's office filled in all the forms and negotiated all the requirements—not an easy task to please some 20 ministers and 70 staff. Vicki from the general manager's office took all the calls and kept the onlookers informed, as it was still business as usual at council. Paul Sutton and his team got all those little fiddly jobs done and kept us calm by personally solving any problems that arose.

Bob Hatchett and his team organised all the technology and the extra phone, fax, PA, lines, et cetera, that were required for the duration. Geoff over at the School of Arts made sure that the whole building was spick and span and even protected the last of the roses outside and coaxed them into continuing to blossom just a little longer for us. Never has the School of Arts looked so good. All the while Graham Napper, the general manager, just smiled and said, `Yes, of course, Jo.' I am not sure where he keeps that smile when he is sleeping, for I know we have brought him some nightmares.

Captain Geoff Cole and his executive officer, Commander Mark Jerrett, were at HMAS Albatross to make sure that everything at the base ran smoothly and kept a weather eye on the `Red Baron' and the other planes. David, the driver from a local bus company, Premier Coaches, looked after the ministers' transport for the day. Superintendent Allan Crumpton's men and women unobtrusively ensured that we could move in and out of buildings without hindrance. Their calm demeanour ensured that no situation became unruly, yet everyone got their say—as is our right in a democracy.

The council catering staff certainly accommodated everyone's needs for regular refreshment. We not only looked after the ministers and cabinet staff but also we jointly fed the press and all of the demonstrators too. Never let anyone find fault with Gilmore's and Shoalhaven's hospitality. Speaking of food, when we initially indicated that the Shoalhaven Rural Volunteer Fire Service was going to provide the lunch, I could tell from the exchanged glances that people were wondering just what might arrive on their plates. They need not have worried. Mary Reeves and her eager and enthusiastic team were determined to make their mark. It seems that these volunteers can produce anything and work with everything or nothing on tap. Lunch for 20 politicians—and 550-odd guests—in a hall with few facilities was a walk in the park. I think the major attraction for her team was the pyjama party in the hall the night before. Stories from that are still filtering out into the community. Shoalhaven's fire control officer, Superintendent Brian Parry, has every reason to be proud of his volunteers. They are wonderful every time. As people entered the School of Arts for the lunch, they were greeted by the Shoalhaven contingent of the Australia 2000 choir. Everyone was amazed at the talent of the choir and not at all surprised to hear that they will form part of the massed choir to sing at the Olympic Games later this year.

Katie McNamara, Shoalhaven Primary School's most recent prime minister, welcomed the `other Prime Minister' on behalf of our young people. She thanked John Howard for helping to provide a campus of Wollongong University locally so that she and others do not have to move away when they reach 17 and want further education. Of course there were numerous volunteers helping my staff and they too are to be congratulated. Without them, we could not do what we do. Lastly, I thank my Prime Minister and his cabinet for mixing so freely with our community. Many had travelled long distances to attend and many had never before been to such a function. I was and I am very proud of our community and how welcome they made our guests. Regardless of political persuasion, people are saying how surprised they are at the difference between the real thing and the media's portrayal of our ministers. Indeed, someone said to me just yesterday, `Your John Howard seems a real decent bloke, and he's much taller than little Bobby Hawke.'

talk.start.para: —Since the announcement of the successful tenders for the second round of the Job Network in December last year, the Minister for Employment Services has continually and repeatedly stressed the importance of the number of sites that the new Job Network provides, claiming that the total number of sites has increased by 700 from 1,400 to 2,100. Any sane person would take the minister's words to mean that there are now going to be literally hundreds of extra locations around the country from which the unemployed can seek assistance. Indeed, the minister has constantly repeated this claim in press releases and on several occasions in this place. For instance, last week he continually talked about the number of sites, saying that this was the most important aspect of the second round of Job Network. Situations have now arisen where, even if you believe that this is the crucial aspect of Job Network 2, no longer can we be confident that the number of sites where unemployed people will be able to access Job Network has necessarily increased by so great a figure.

speech.para: Last week I discovered that three of the so-called new sites in my electorate would be operating out of the same office. `One site, three providers' gets counted as three different sites—another example of the way in which the Howard government short-changes the unemployed. The interesting aspect about this is that, in the guff that the minister sends around in support of this new beaut Job Network system, he describes the location Epping as having gone from having a CES site to having two sites under Job Network 1 and to now having eight sites under Job Network 2 over the course of the Job Network. The irony is that the location which now houses three sites, as I have mentioned, is the old CES site. The minister came down last Friday and opened one of the service provider offices. He has also indicated—and he confirmed the strong rumour—that the Salvation Army, who are situated across the road, will shift their site to the same location. So we will have the four providers on the one site. This has been described by the minister as showing the way in which his Job Network 2 is so successful and will give the unemployed such great choices.

Throughout the announcements about Job Network 2, the crucial aspect that has not been revealed by the minister is the number of unemployed people who will be able to be helped by Job Network 2. That is the thing that is crucial to the 5,000-odd people that are unemployed in the electorate of Scullin. They do not necessarily want to be browbeaten and told suddenly that, because there is an increased number of sites, it is a better system. At the end of the day, when the contractual requirements are fulfilled and the maximum number of unemployed people that each service can carry is reached, there will still be people who will be unable to access Job Network. These are the figures that the minister should come clean on. He should not only explain to us what is going to happen under Job Network 2 but also convert some of the propaganda that he has circulated about Job Network 1 into actual numbers. Mr Speaker, you will remember that the figures that have been circulated are percentage success figures.

At the end of the day, what the minister has to realise when he comes into this place is that at the sharp end of these programs are real people. These are the people who really want to know what is in it for them. He crows from a piece of paper that he thinks that there are more sites. That is not going to give the number of people who saw no success out of Job Network 1 any sense of satisfaction. I think that the honourable minister really has to look at the way in which he projects and promotes Job Network 2 to understand that the people who are requiring assistance are not interested in the number of sites that they can attend; they are interested in a job as an outcome. Until we make that the crucial connection in the promotion of these schemes to help unemployed people, we are underrating the potential for any assistance that government can give. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: McEwen Electorate: Thornton Primary School Anniversary

talk.start.para: —I would like to share with the House this evening a most wonderful event that I attended last Saturday in my electorate in the very small town of Thornton. It was a very special day for the people of Thornton because they were celebrating the 130th anniversary of the Thornton Primary School. In 1870 a number of the residents of Thornton and others living in the Rubicon Valley approached the then Public Schools Office—as I believe it was known then—in Victoria. They advised that office that there were 70 children in the district and that they felt that that was a reasonable number of children to warrant the erection of a primary school. Until that time, some children were being educated by governesses and others were getting whatever education they could get at home. The Board of Education agreed to this proposal and erected a weatherboard building consisting of one room. One teacher came to the school, and a section was partitioned off in the corner of the room, which was in fact where the teacher slept. The 70 students varied in age from four to 16, and they were all accommodated in this one room.

speech.para: The fact that this school has succeeded over that period of 130 years is just incredible. It really has depended on tremendous community spirit, and last Saturday's most spectacular event was evidence of that fact. The start of the program saw four students, led by Holly Deacon, lower the old flag at the school and hoist a new flag, which I had just presented to the students. Those four students rep-resented five generations who had attended that school. It was a most moving day, and I want to place on the record the thanks that should go to Mr Greg Nippard, the school council president, and the many people who assisted him. Tonight, I also want to place on the record a ballad written by Leanne Scorah. It really sums up what the Rubicon Valley was like in the past, and the spirit and atmosphere that have come down through the century and that have been built into and still pervade the Thornton Primary School today. The ballad is simply called `Rubicon' and it begins with:

quote.para: When I came to Rubicon, many years ago
I never thought I'd last a week, now that was sixty-one years ago
I started off at Skinners Mill, wheelin' sawdust to a heap.
Stackin' droppers onto bogie's, and learned to count in superfeet
I became a foreman in the bush, with new mills on the go
A pelton wheel to drive the bench, saw workers come and go
Horse and bogie's on the track, movin' down the line
Life line of the forest, was the timber tramway line
My Rose, she came to Rubicon, to make my hut a home
To build with me a future, that we could call our own
Handwork in the evenings, picnics by the creek
Bushwalks on the weekends, bring back fond memories.

speech.para: The ballad goes on, but I will just recite the chorus as I realise that I am out of time. It reads:

quote.para: Rubicon, Oh Rubicon, your valleys and your trees
Your glory stands above me, your waters running free
Rubicon, Oh Rubicon, the power in you grows
Your beauty it surrounds me, and your gentle breezes blow.

speech.para: Those words were written to honour Ern and Rose Le Brun who, like so many other people of the Rubicon district and the town of Thornton, were responsible for keeping the Thornton Primary School alive, providing a continuous education to the families and children of Thornton.

talk.start.para: —Last week many in the House had the opportunity to pay tribute to our INTERFET forces and their commanding officer, Major General Cosgrove, for the superb service they carried out in East Timor, and it was right and proper that we did so. All in the House and in the wider Australian community were very impressed by the fantastic job our forces—members of the Army, Navy and Air Force—did during their sojourn in East Timor. Like most Australians, I watched as the East Timorese saga unfolded and the Australian military build-up occurred. The media, being what they are, obviously focused on the key players—the movers and shakers—as the time drew near for our troops to leave our shores. Too often in situations like this, we forget what a wonderful team our INTERFET force is and that it is made up of individuals—highly trained, highly skilled young Australian men and women. Tonight I want to place on record a simple tribute to one of these INTERFET members: an ordinary young Tasmanian who is a serviceman from my electorate. He has just returned from East Timor and is currently enjoying some well deserved R&R with his family.

speech.para: Mark Rankin is a young 20-year-old from Gagebrook, an outer suburb in Hobart. He and his parents, Barbara and Mal Rankin, live less than two kilometres from my electorate office. Mark is an air defence guard with 2AFDS RAAF, based at Amberley in Queensland, and served five months deployment with the RAAF in East Timor. Mark relished the chance to serve his country with the INTERFET forces and seized the invaluable opportunity to put into practice in a war zone what he had learned while being stationed at Amberley. I congratulate him and the many other Tasmanians who served with distinction in East Timor. They continue the proud tradition of Australian servicemen and servicewomen who readily answer the call to serve their nation, both at home and overseas.

talk.start.para: —I came across an interesting article in yesterday's Australian by Robert Gottliebson. The article is headed `Spending $7bn on Badgerys Creek is plane silly'. I have to agree with a number of the comments that Mr Gottliebson made in this article. He talked firstly about the massive and excessive cost that this proposal would incur—$7 billion. As the EIS estimates, there is at least $5 billion for the airport itself and another $2 billion or $3 billion for associated infrastructure—a cost all up of at least $7 billion to $8 billion to taxpayers. Mr Gottliebson said:

quote.para: Once again a group of public servants will try to get Badgerys Creek passed, even though the project represents potentially the greatest waste of money contemplated in modern Australia.

speech.para: Added to that is the fact that world experience shows that, particularly in cities the size of Sydney, second airports rarely work. They are rarely viable. There are many examples: Mirabel in Montreal, Los Angeles, et cetera. Even after spending $8 billion, we could well end up with a non-viable, loss making Badgerys Creek airport. That loss would mean that, when the eventual privatisation of Sydney airport comes, there will be a further loss on the sale price—there will be a reduced sale price—that Sydney airport would bring.

The second point that Robert Gottliebson makes in this article is that the need for a second airport is very doubtful. It has not been proven. He said in this article, and while you might not agree with everything he uses to prove the point, with appropriate management techniques you can make Mascot last another 25 years. He points out that Sydney airport has the capacity and is already licensed for 350,000 movements a year and that it is currently running only at about 282,000. The average number of passengers in a flight in and out of Mascot is around 75 people. World best practice is over 150 on each flight in and out of an international airport. One-third of the flights in and out of Mascot are on planes carrying 30 passengers or less.

There are many better alternatives to building a second airport at Badgerys Creek. There are better management possibilities for better balancing the peaks and troughs of flight time arrivals and departures at Mascot. The introduction of new technologies such as a differential global positioning system, which will allow greater geographical spreading and sharing of aircraft noise, the movement of some of the lighter aircraft out to Bankstown, and thereby reducing the interval between departure and landing times of aircraft and the exclusion of some of the smaller curfew exempt aircraft from the movements cap by, for instance, utilising a stub runway are some of the many options that could be used before going down the path of wastefully spending $7 billion to $8 billion of taxpayers' money.

Mr Gottliebson argues for moving some of the regionals out to Bankstown. Clearly there needs to be protection for regional airline users—there needs to be some protection for the bush. There needs to be some access for the bush to Mascot, but by moving some of the lighter aircraft—those carrying, say, 20 passengers or less—out to a special purpose-built facility at Bankstown with dedicated transport links to Sydney, we could guarantee access in peak timeslots and reduce the pressure on Mascot. We could provide discounted air fares and we could provide slot trading to enable savings for regional airlines that would bring benefits to many of the users from the bush. The savings are there. As the Sydney Morning Herald said in an article last year,

quote.para: The saga of the $5 billion Badgerys Creek airport plan is becoming increasingly bizarre. It is also becoming increasingly obvious that Badgerys Creek is not an appropriate site for a second Sydney airport.

speech.para: The article goes on to say:

quote.para: The Badgerys Creek option, therefore, merely moves some of the noise problems at Mascot to areas out of Sydney.

speech.para: There are better options. We need to be pursuing those better options before we go down the path of spending $7 billion to $8 billion of taxpayers' money on an airport that will not solve Sydney's problems and will not provide any guarantees to the bush but will duplicate those problems. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week the member for Wentworth used this parliament in the most scandalous way to abuse my constituents, the residents and businesspeople of Kings Cross. The member for Wentworth called them `pimps and pushers and crims; killers, junkies, perverts, deros, standover men, whores, hoods and gangsters.' He is just wrong, and he insults the people of Kings Cross with this description. The overwhelming majority of residents of Kings Cross and its neighbouring suburbs are law-abiding citizens who love an inner city lifestyle. The Cross is a tourism magnet with some of the best large and small boutique hotels in Sydney. We have a great restaurant culture and a thriving local arts community run by the Kings Cross Artists Guild. We have an active chamber of commerce and residents groups that are constantly working to improve our area. We have our problems, like any other part of Sydney, but the residents and business people of the Cross are not helped by the sort of vilification that the member for Wentworth poured on them last week.

—Tonight I speak on behalf of constituents of mine, Mr Paul and Mrs Annette Cahill, who have a son Paul, 10 years of age, who suffers from the terrible disease of cystic fibrosis. In his short life he has had over 30 admissions to hospital, many of these times in intensive care, and he has had a liver transplant and major bowel surgery. Mrs Cahill wrote to me recently, asking me to send a message to the Minister for Family and Community Services. The message to Senator Newman read:

quote.para: Senator Newman, you have been misinformed about Cystic Fibrosis. These children need care and attention far and above the care of a `normal child', yet our Federal Government feels this is not so. I am extending a personal invitation to Senator Jocelyn Newman to come and live at my house for one month and to take over the day to day care of my son and then let us see how her cost saving measures are well intentioned. Senator Newman, you can also move into Children's Hospital at Westmead and stay with a Cystic Fibrosis child and sit by their bed as they gasp for breath, fading away in front of your eyes, full of pain.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, I call on the members of the government side to reverse the evil decision made by Senator Newman and to listen to the heart-rending pleas made by families of cystic fibrosis sufferers. The quality of life of children afflicted by this tragic disease should be enhanced by allowing the family of sufferers to access the CDA. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate the member for Bradman for his strong stance in support of the victims of cystic fibrosis and their families.

—Mr Speaker, I do not wish to detain the House for long, but I thought it was appropriate to respond briefly to some comments made earlier in the adjournment debate by the member for Scullin. The member for Scullin took me to task for `failing to state what the real numbers of employment outcomes, job network outcomes, are'. He said that I was dwelling exclusively—obsessively, he said—on site numbers and not on the overall performance of the Job Network.

speech.para: To satisfy the member for Scullin, let me give him some of those numbers that he seeks. In the first 22 months of operation, from 1 May 1998 to 25 February 2000, there were more than 494,000 placements of eligible clients into jobs through Job Network. Of total eligible placements, about 60 per cent have been into permanent jobs. In the last 12 months Job Network placed an average of nearly 6,000 eligible clients per week into jobs. For February 2000, on like-for-like basis, Job Network placed nearly 50 per cent more eligible job seekers than did the CES in February 1998. This is typical of the overall performance on a month by month basis of the Job Network vis-a-vis the old CES. From 1 May 1998 to 25 February 2000, 93,000 jobs seekers commenced Jobsearch training. In the same period there were around 26,000 job matching eligible placements for job seekers who received Jobsearch training.

Almost 527,000 job seekers commenced intensive assistance from 1 May 1998 to 25 February 2000. The targeting of intensive assistance to job seekers most disadvantaged in the labour market has proven to be particularly effective, with nearly 70 per cent of total intensive assistance commencements being long-term unemployed. In this period Job Network members made over 165,000 job matching placements for long-term unemployed and other disadvantaged job seekers receiving intensive assistance, which is approximately 33 per cent of all eligible job matching placements under the Job Network. I should add that the Job Network's intensive assistance and job search training programs have a 43 per cent success rate of helping participants find paid employment or further educational study opportunities. This compares with an overall success rate of 34 per cent for Working Nation programs.

The member for Scullin also said that despite the increase in site numbers, the actual quantum of employment services was not going to increase. I have here some figures prepared by my department. In 1999, some 308,000 job matching placements were made. In the first 12 months of Job Network 2, it is anticipated that 400,000 job matching placements will be made. In 1999, there were nearly 54,000 Jobsearch training com-mencements. In the first 12 months of Job Network 2, it is anticipated that there will be nearly 90,000 Jobsearch training com-mence-ments. In 1999, there were 254,000 intensive assistance commencements. It is anticipated that, in the first 12 months of Job Network 2, there will be 275,000 intensive assistance commencements.

I am delighted that the member for Scullin noticed the fact that I did launch Job Network 2 in Victoria at Sarina Russo Job Access in Epping, in his electorate, the other day; and, yes, it is true that there will shortly be four Job Network members operating on the one large site. It is true that when we have four Job Network members operating out of the one building we do not get some benefits, but we do get other benefits. The shadow minister at the table, Mr Laurie Ferguson, is very familiar with Parramatta Road, which runs through his electorate. Parramatta Road, as we know, is the centre of the motor industry. If it had one big car yard, it would not be nearly as effective as it is with lots of big car yards. The fact is that with those four Job Network agencies—those four sites in the one building—we get competition plus choice, and that equals better service. And that is what the Job Network is all about: better service to jobseekers.

In the old days under Labor, when unemployment reached 11.2 per cent, there were just 400 CES sites around the country. Today under the coalition, with unem-ployment at 6.7 per cent, we have nearly 2,100 Job Network sites around the country, and I think we deserve a little bit of credit. It is true that jobseekers want jobs rather than services. In the end, the services are missing the point unless jobs come from them, but the fact is that 600,000 new jobs have been created since the coalition came into government—that is 600,000 very grateful jobseekers. They are grateful but it seems members opposite, par--ticularly the member for Scullin, do not share their gratitude; but that is the sort of thing you expect, unfortunately, from people who are professional cynics and sceptics.

(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

—On Friday, 3 March, the federal government committed $18.5 million in funding under the Roads of National Importance Program towards the cost of constructing the Gillman Highway in my electorate of Port Adelaide. The state government in South Australia will also contribute $18.5 million to this highway and have indicated their support for a privately built and operated bridge across the Port River. This will connect the Gillman Highway with Victoria Road, the main arterial road on the Le Fevre Peninsula leading to the Outer Harbour shipping terminals. It will result in significant savings, particularly for South Australia's booming export industries.

speech.para: The Gillman Highway and Port River Bridge are vital for the economic development of South Australia. This can be demonstrated by the fact that this is the first project funded by the federal government's Roads of National Importance Program which has gone to a Labor area. There is not the usual pork-barrelling of marginal seats which we have all become used to. This project is the final jigsaw piece of the transport network in the north and north-west of Adelaide and will build on the great work already completed by the previous Labor government. This includes the duplication of the national highway from Adelaide to Port Wakefield, the Montague Road realignment, the South Road interconnector and the Salisbury Highway extension with a bridge which spans over Highway 1.

The final piece of the jigsaw may also help expedite the redevelopment of the Port Adelaide area as a thriving residential, cultural and commercial centre. What does concern me, though, is not the funding commitment of the Commonwealth nor the state government's good intention to complete this project. It is the incompetence of senior management in the South Australian government departments that concerns me. I would have to question whether the current senior officers of the Department of Industry and Trade, the Land Management Corporation, state Treasury and the Department of Environment, Heritage and Aboriginal Affairs have the capability to implement such a project without creating considerable delays of their own making. I hope I am wrong, yet the evidence so far suggests I will not be.

Take, for example, the Gillman land capability study. I understand it is long overdue and is now reaching the fourth draft report. It has not yet been seen by the Minister for Industry and Trade, the minister responsible for initiating the report in the first place. Another example is the Lipson Street wharf development, a major riverfront residential development, which was seen as a litmus test for future success or otherwise of rejuvenating the Port Adelaide area. After all government agencies had agreed and signed off on the fine details, the project was held up for months as the developers could not get new deeds of title for the land division from the bureaucracy.

Unless the state government acts now and streamlines the administrative processes within the bureaucracy in South Australia, the bridge and Gillman Highway could be delayed longer than potential developers of the Port Adelaide area are prepared to wait. Investors are already frustrated with their inability to negotiate with the Public Service in South Australia. Any more delays may just as well be a window of opportunity lost for another 10 years or so.

talk.start.para: —At the moment Australia is focused upon and looks forward with great anticipation to the Olympic Games in Sydney in just six months time. It is an exciting and historic time for us. It is the culmination of years of planning, preparation and training for so many athletes, trainers, organisers and sports fans. But it is important that we remember that, when the Olympics have come to a successful conclusion, we are in for another world-class display of athleticism, courage and competition when the Paralympic cauldron is lit on 18 October. Just as our athletes around the nation are building their training regimes to peak for the Olympics, so too are our paralympians doing so.

speech.para: I was delighted and proud to catch up last week with one of my local constituents who is training for the Paralympics. Reg Wilkinson is a very inspirational man. He is a successful businessman owning and operating Palm Beach Automotive Repairs. He and his wife Karen have four beautiful daughters. He is an amputee and a paracycling champion. Although Reg has only been training and competing professionally for less than six months, he won both the 4,000- and 1,000-metre track events in the paracycling division at the Queensland cycling championship in Townsville earlier this year.

He is now training and fund raising for the opportunity to compete against the world in Sydney in October. I wish Reg well and urge McPherson residents to join me in supporting Reg's efforts to raise enough funds to be able to represent us at the Paralympics. We are huge sports fans on the Gold Coast, with our city playing host to a plethora of national and international sporting events. We are also a pretty generous bunch, so I hope we all get behind Reg. He is a truly inspirational man. I congratulate him on his success to date and wish him the best for October and the future.

I also want to take this opportunity to say how pleased I am to be part of the Parliamentarians for the Paralympics. The aim of our group is to raise awareness and support within the Australian community for the Paralympic Games and to encourage attendance as spectators. I am very proud to be patron of the table tennis event at the Paralympics. I will take this opportunity to remind honourable members and others listening of the major fundraising event, Quilts 2000, taking place next month in Parliament House. The quilting fraternity of Australia has joined to create some historic quilts highlighting the Australian landscape and culture and promoting the Paralympics. These quilts are for sale and will be on display from Wednesday, 12 April in the Presiding Officers exhibition area here in Parliament House and ultimately will be displayed in the athletes village during both the Olympics and Paralympics. I urge everyone's support for Quilts 2000 and I encourage people from around the nation to lend their support and join in the excitement and inspiration that will be the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games from 18 to 29 October.

talk.start.para: —In the 1700s Edmund Burke said, `Your representative owes you not his industry only, but his judgment; and he betrays you instead of serving you if he sacrifices it to your opinion.' The Prime Minister has said that he is opposed to mandatory sentencing, yet instead of showing leadership on this issue he is prepared to allow a young man to die in jail for stealing a few pencils. Last week Alan Bond was released from jail where he spent about one day for every million dollars he stole from his shareholders, and this week the Prime Minister has confirmed he will not allow his party to have a conscience vote on whether to overturn mandatory sentencing in the Northern Territory and Western Australia.

speech.para: Mandatory sentencing costs lives and so qualifies absolutely for the usual tests applied when deciding whether a conscience vote is called for. The real hypocrisy here lies in the fact that the Prime Minister was quite happy to intervene in the Northern Territory's laws on voluntary euthanasia. There was no states' rights argument impeding his interference then, yet when it comes to sending children to jail—or for that matter, sending adults to jail for minor crimes—it is a `hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil' approach. Mandatory sentencing of juveniles is contrary to our international obligations. It breaches article 37(b) and 37(c) of the Convention on the Rights of the Child by arbitrarily depriving children of their liberty, failing to use detention as a last resort, and failing to take the needs of the particular child into account.

It is also in conflict with article 14(5) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and article 40(2)(v) of the Convention of the Rights of the Child which require that sentences should be reviewable by a higher appellate court. Mandatory sentencing is poor law. It does not distinguish serious crime from petty crime and so undermines completely judicial discretion. That is why so many senior judges have condemned it.

Mandatory sentencing is poor economics also. According to the Northern Territory Department of Correctional Services annual report for 1997-98, it cost $56,669.90 to incarcerate a person for a year. How much more effective would that money be spent on childhood education, health care, housing or employment programs? If the Northern Territory government are really interested in addressing crime rates they could spend the millions of dollars given to them by the taxpayers of other states on positive not punitive measures.

The United States has recently incarcerated its two millionth citizen. Most Americans in jail are jailed for drug related offences, yet the drug usage in the community continues to rise. In Australia we must now decide whether we are any better than the United States and whether we are prepared to allow children to die in jail for stealing pencils or biscuits.

talk.start.para: —In the short time I have available for me today, I would like to correct some dreadful and misleading information that has been peddled around the Redcliffe City Council elections. Currently, I have seen some brochures that say that a vote for the Boulton-led council is a vote for John Howard and the GST and that every resident will pay an additional $1,600 on their rates. Not only is that misleading; it is just plain wrong.

speech.para: One of the most important things that needs to be remembered in all of this is that local governments will be great beneficiaries of the goods and services tax. They will also be able to claim back embedded taxes on all the services they use. Communication services will be cheaper for them by about four per cent; repair services will be six per cent cheaper; business services 2.5 per cent cheaper; and a lot of their services, such as marketing and accounting, will also be cheaper. They can also claim back full input tax credits should their costs fall by about 2.5 per cent. There will also be no GST on water, sewerage or waste, and they will be able to deliver those services at a low cost.

When I became the member for Petrie in 1996 the Redcliffe area was a very depressed area, and a lot of credit needs to be given to Mayor Boulton and his team for the subsequent turnaround. Many of my colleagues and friends wished me well. Redcliffe was called a number of things, including `Deadcliffe', which was not terribly complimentary. It was also called `Inala by the Sea', and as Inala is a very tough area of Brisbane, that certainly was not a complimentary name. But now we have people coming back to the city of Redcliffe. The mayor and the council have reduced the crime rate in the area; they have developed the foreshore; they have upgraded and built a new jetty; and they have a vision business advisory group that has produced its own ads encouraging people to visit the Redcliffe Peninsula. We have reintroduced the Sun Girls, and last week some 20,000 people came to a concert with Marcia Hines. There are export forums, new businesses are opening, and development is occurring on the Redcliffe Peninsula.

People no longer say to me, `Gee, it is a tough area, I wish you well.' They are now saying, `Look, I would not mind coming down to Redcliffe and having lunch at one of those wonderful seafood restaurants.' What has been the reason for that? The area was depressed, no businesses were investing, it had a terrible attitude problem, and the residents themselves were depressed. I remember attending a forum in parliament for senior students where one of the students who attended the forum came from Redcliffe. I asked her what she was going to do after she finished school and she said to me, `I am looking forward to leaving Redcliffe.' Well, that is not the case any more.

This council should be judged on its merits. It should be judged on the success that it has had over the last few years and not judged on things that are external. If it is judged on its merits, it deserves to be reinstated. I want to congratulate Councillor Boulton, his deputy Councillor Sutherland, and all of the councillors of Redcliffe City Council for the wonderful work that they put into the development of Redcliffe.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I call on the federal government to immediately reject applications by Impulse and Virgin to use large passenger aircraft at Essendon Airport, including the 100-passenger 717s proposed by Impulse, and the 150-passenger 737s proposed by Virgin.
—What about Avalon?

—Indeed. It was alarming to read in the BRW in January that Impulse seriously proposes to use Essendon as a base for Boeing 717-200s. It is even more alarming that transport minister Anderson has still not replied to my letter to him of 12 January on this issue. I call on him to publicly rule out the reintroduction of large passenger jets to Essendon. I assure him and anybody else who is interested that if any attempt is made to do this there will be hundreds of people lying on the tarmac, just as hundreds of people attended protest rallies concerning this issue called by state member Judy Maddigan and myself earlier this year.

speech.para: Secondly, I call on the federal government, through the Airports Corporation, to re-examine the airport curfew and to ensure that residents can get a decent night's sleep. I have had a reply from the Essendon Airport general manager to a letter I wrote to him after receiving complaints from local residents that planes were landing and taking off at 2 a.m. and 3 a.m. In it he confirms that planes are indeed taking off at 3 a.m. in a regular freight operation. He also states that the majority of propeller driven aircraft are not subject to the curfew. This is just not good enough. If the justification for allowing planes to land or take off at that time is that they are quiet or meet the noise requirements, then why are they waking up Strathmore and Essendon residents? Clearly, the curfew is inadequate and ineffective, and it needs to be toughened up and properly enforced.

Finally, I want to congratulate the state Labor government on not offering local residents as a sacrificial lamb in its bid to secure the Virgin headquarters for Melbourne. I heard the Liberal opposition leader in Victoria, Denis Napthine, saying on radio that this would not have happened under the previous Premier, Jeff Kennett. Apart from noting that he did not say that it would not have happened under him, my response is this: perhaps Jeff Kennett would have told Virgin, `Yes, you can fly 150-seat passenger aircraft out of Essendon.' He showed absolute contempt for the people of Niddrie over the quarry; he showed absolute contempt for the people of Werribee in relation to the toxic dump site; and he showed absolute contempt for the people of the north-western suburbs of Melbourne by imposing a toll on the Tullamarine Freeway. But we now have a state government which does not trample on local communities like that and, surely, after seven years we are entitled to a few years of a government which does not trample on local communities. I am proud to be a Labor representative when we have a state government that respects local communities, and I give Victoria's Acting Premier in January, John Thwaites, 10 out of 10 for the way he handled the Virgin issue.

talk.start.para: —With the regular season of the Australian National Basketball League now at an end, the Townsville Crocodiles find themselves potentially just four games away from securing the championship title. The Townsville Crocs have had a remarkable year. They have finished the regular season in second place behind the Adelaide 36ers.

speech.para: The statistics speak for themselves: a 22 to 6 win-loss record throughout the season, equal to that of Adelaide and the Perth Wildcats. Two Crocs players, Sam Mackinnon and Robert Rose, are in the running for the NBL's Most Valuable Player award. Another Croc, Mike Kelly, has been nominated as Best Defensive Player. Townsville strong man Andrew Goodwin has been nominated for Most Improved Player and Ben Knight is in the running for the NBL's Best Sixth Man award. The Townsville Crocs go into the play-offs having won their last seven games on the trot, including strong victories over Melbourne and Adelaide. The basketball-mad community of Townsville and Thuringowa fans are behind them 100 per cent.

I remember reflecting in this place on the Townsville Crocodiles when I made my first speech as the federal member for Herbert. In that year, the then Suns finished in the league at the bottom of the competition table, but that did not stop Townsville's legion of basketball fans turning out week after week, filling the entertainment centre with some 5,000 or 6,000 people in support of the Crocs. So breaking into the elite ranks of the game was always going to be a long haul, but this year it has been the coming of age for the Townsville Crocs. As one news story reported the other day:

quote.para: Townsville will go down in the books as the most potent, all-round offensive unit in NBL history after becoming the first team to finish the season atop the rankings in points scored per game, field goal percentage and three point percentage.

speech.para: Quite an achievement, don't you agree, Mr Deputy Speaker? The Townsville Crocs chairman, David Carmichael, the other day reflected perfectly the pride with which Townsville holds his team when he said:

quote.para: We're the second smallest city in the NBL but we've got one of the best teams. It's been a great effort for everyone involved with the club and we've got a great group of fans.

speech.para: In fact, we have got such a great group of fans that there is just not going to be enough room at the 5,257-seat Townsville entertainment centre for everyone who wants to see the Crocs win in the coming NBL play-offs. The last home season game against Adelaide was sold out many days in advance of the game itself. Yesterday they put 1,300 tickets on sale for the play-offs and they were sold out in three hours—a wonderful response of the Townsville community. I certainly wish the Crocs well and I reckon they have got the get-up-and-go to grab the championship title.

talk.start.para: —After the contribution by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert, about the Townsville Crocs, I suppose it is appropriate that we go into a debate on fisheries. But let me say the Townsville Crocs must be a team with real bite in the competition. I actually had a meeting this morning with a representative of Recfish from Townsville, Mr Vern Veitch, and I will be visiting Townsville in coming months. Maybe the championship will be all over by the time I get there, but we certainly do wish the Crocs well.
—We will look after you with northern hospitality.

—I am sure you will. The Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999, amends the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 by introducing new measures for monitoring and control of foreign and domestic fishing operations. It also proposes some changes to the way in which the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, AFMA, operates. These measures are meant to complement the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Act 1999 and the Border Protection Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999, which both provide for combating illegal foreign fishing in the Australian fishing zone and the implementation of Australia's international obligations under the Fish Stocks Agreement. Those were two pieces of legislation on which the opposition supported the government. It was a Labor government that signed Australia up to those international obligations under the UN Fish Stocks Agreement, and we were pleased to see that the legislation gave effect to the intent of the Labor government at that time.

speech.para: For the benefit of the Main Committee I will run through some of the main provisions of this bill. One provision is to place observers on foreign fishing vessels operating in international waters, where such observers are authorised by a treaty or agreement to which Australia is a party. It is very important for the verification of the obligations of international fishers that we exercise our rights, under treaties or agreements to which we are a party, to place observers on foreign fishing vessels. We have a particular problem with illegal fishing inside the Australian fishing zone and the overfishing of straddling stocks outside the Australian fishing zone in international waters. This provision is very important to the monitoring task that Australia must undertake if it wants to protect fisheries which may be low volume fisheries by world standards but which are certainly high value fisheries in the Australian and international context.

Another provision is to extend the definition of foreign fishing boats to include support vessels and vessels not originally designed for fishing but subsequently equipped to fish. This will allow the government to deny port access to such vessels. In the past, vessels have been converted and used as mother ships to support fishing activities that sometimes are illegal. We need to deny those vessels port access in Australia, to make it even more difficult for them to carry out their illegal activities, both within the zone and outside the zone.

The legislation provides for an increase in the penalty for providing false or misleading information about fish taken, processed or carried under a fishing concession from $6,600 to $27,500. It also allows a court to tailor a period for which a fishing concession may be suspended following a breach of conditions. This would allow a court to suspend a fisher's concession for a period coinciding with the fishing season in which the person normally operates. The objective of these two provisions is to increase the penalty burden, be it financial or a denial to that fisher of access to the fishery for the period of the season. These are good, sensible amendments and we are supporting them.

The legislation requires fishers to collect data on bycatch of both fish and non-fish species, including sea birds, and it requires AFMA to include in management plans provisions directed at minimising incidental catch. The provision relating to the collection of data on bycatch of both fish and non-fish species is an important one. This is a very contentious area of policy but it is very important, not only for the industry but also for government in its monitoring of the environmental consequences of fishing and in addressing the sustainability issues, that these provisions are put in place.

Australian fisheries are well managed. Internationally speaking, we have a very good reputation for the way in which we manage our fisheries. That is not to say that, historically, things have not occurred which governments have not agreed with. The fishing industry has in the past had a reputation for activities that have put the sustainability of many of our fisheries in jeopardy.

Gradually, with the regional fishing management plans being put in place, and increasing sensitivity within the industry that they need to address these sustainability issues if they are going to have a real future, understanding is coming through. The sorts of provisions in this legislation certainly assist the monitoring process and protect these fisheries in a sustainable way. It is not only the industry that relies on this particular resource but many coastal regions and towns are very dependent on the processing and value adding activities of the fishing industry. It is incumbent on government to make sure that the resource is sustainable and that illegal fishing activities that deplete the resource and affect the sustainability of the resource are addressed as well.

This particular legislation also allows AFMA to manage and carry out adjustments, restructuring and exploratory and feasibility programs devised by other agencies or within the government, and it makes AFMA liable to pay fringe benefits tax. Those are more minor amendments to the legislation that we are discussing here today. I want to make some comment on this particular industry because it does offer Australia real potential not only for employment growth but also for export growth. We have seen production volumes increase in value from $1.6 billion in 1995-96 to $1.8 billion in 1998-99. Export value over that particular time has increased dramatically from $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion. That is a substantial industry and contributor to Australia's national exporting effort. Indeed, if we do protect the sustainability of this resource we can look forward to future discoveries as far as fisheries are concerned.

If the management practices are put in place and the industry handles the sustainability issue carefully, we can look forward to sustained growth over time in both the volume of production and the value of that production. In 1998-99 the value of production of sectors within the fishing industry was as follows: rock lobsters $385 million; prawns $310 million; pearls $238 million; abalone $184 million and tuna $121 million. We are dealing here with very high value fish stocks. Because they are high value they are sought after and become the target for illegal fishers. The legislation that we are debating here today is an ongoing and evolving process of strengthening Australia's legislation in this area to protect this very valuable resource, not only to the national economy but to many coastal and regional economies as well. It is time that industry and government seriously addressed the sustainability issue. We have been making gains in that area over the last 10 to 15 years.

In the legislation that has been brought down by the government and supported by the opposition on the floor of the parliament, there are measures to ensure that illegal activity, both within the Australian fishing zone and outside of it, in violation of regional agreements that have been struck, have appropriate penalties. We ought to have no hesitation at all in seizing vessels that we know are violating those regional agreements and illegally fishing in our zone or outside of it.

Statistics on illegal boats caught operating in our zones show that 285 foreign vessels were apprehended in the Australian fishing zone between 1 March 1996 and 31 December 1999. A lot of those were what we call type II and type III fishing vessels. That refers to the different styles of Indonesian fishing boats that have been apprehended inside the Australian fishing zone. But the more ominous development is the `other' category. These are flags of convenience or Chinese Taipei flagged ships which are operating illegally outside our fishing zone. Over the period 1996-98, we have seen what you would call a significant increase in the number of ships of this category.
